Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

On June 16, 2020, a special investigation was initiated into the allegations
described above. Agency staff were interviewed as well as the complainant.
Documents were reviewed. What follows is information obtained from the
aforementioned sources.
2

ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that the agency worker was not making the required monthly
visits to the home.
INVESTIGATION:
On June 16, 2020, a telephone call was placed to the Complainant and a message
left.
On July 1, 2020 a phone interview was conducted with the Complainant. She offered
the following information. She reported that the agency Foster Care Worker, hereafter
referred to as Staff 1, was not making visits to the foster home as required. She also
reported that Staff 1 and the agency Supervisor falsified documentation of a home
visit contact. The Complainant reported that the submission of a service plan to the
Court was late and that parent progress on goals were not documented. The
Complainant further reported that the agency had not followed up on reasonable
efforts towards reunification.
On August 27, 2020 the agency Chief Administrator was interviewed. She reported
that a January 22, 2020 social work contact was listed as a foster home visit but was
a parenting time visit in the bio-parents home. She reported that the contact narrative
indicates that the visit was a parenting time visit in the bio-parents home. The Chief
Administrator reported that Staff 1 mistakenly entered that the visit was a foster home
visit.
Document Review:
A review of the social work contacts indicates that the January 22, 2020 visit is
documented as a visit to the foster home yet the narrative indicates that the visit was
to the bio-parent home. Additional review of the contacts indicates that there were no
visits by Staff 1 to the foster home for January 2020 and March, 2020, and no visit to
the home occurred in November 2019.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at
least once every month.
3

ANALYSIS: The Chief Administrator acknowledged that the January 22,
2020 visit was a parenting time visit at the bio-parents home and
not a visit to the foster home as listed on the contact.
The review of contacts indicates that monthly contacts to the
foster home did not occur in November 2019, and January
2020. There was not a video conference contact with the foster
family in March 2020.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that a staff person and the supervisor falsified a social work
contact.
During the interview with the Chief Administrator on August 27, 2020, she reported
that it was believed that Staff 1 mistakenly documented the January 22, 2020 as a
visit to the foster home instead of a parenting time visit. The Chief Administrator
reported that the narrative of the visit indicates that it was to and with the bio-parent
home, not the foster home. The Chief Administrator reported that Staff 1 was a new
employee, hired September 30, 2019, and was struggling meeting the
responsibilities of the position. Staff 1 left the agency on June 19, 2020.
On August 31, 2020, the Clinical Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed. She
reported that Staff 1 was struggling to meet the demands of the position. She
reported that the January 22, 2020 visit to the bio-parent home was mistakenly
documented as a foster home visit. She denied that she knew of any attempt by
Staff 1 to falsify a social work contact. She denied falsifying a social work contact.
Staff 1 was not interviewed as she is no longer employed by the agency.
Document Review:
As indicated previously under the document review above the January 22, 2020,
social work contact narrative suggests that the visit took place in the bio-parent
home and not the foster home.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12206 Staff Qualifications
(1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
contact with children or parents to be a person who has the
ability, experience, education, and training to perform the
duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: The Chief Administrator and Clinical Foster Care Supervisor
reported that identifying the January 22, 2020 visit location as
the foster home was a mistake by Staff 1.
The social work contact suggests that the visit took place in the
bio-parent home and if Staff 1 was attempting to falsify a visit to
the foster home she would not have generated a narrative
indicating that the visit occurred in the foster home, not the bio-
parent home.
The supervisor denied falsifying a social work contact.
Evidence indicates that Staff 1 mistakenly documented the visit
as a visit to the foster home.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that the agency worker did not assess and document parent
progress towards goals in the service plan.
INVESTIGATION:
Document Review:
A review of a service plan and parent/agency treatment plan dated February 21,
2020 to May 20, 2020 lacked documentation of bio-parent progress towards
treatment goals. Where progress should have been documented there was the
word “Partial” with no supporting narrative, or “NA” was indicated.
During the August 27, 2020 interview with the Chief Administrator she could not
account for a lack documented progress and referred me to the program supervisor.
On August 31, 2020, the Clinical Foster Care Supervisor acknowledged there was a
failure to assess bio-parent progress towards goals and document any progress.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information.
(d) Assessment of progress in achieving the permanency
goal for the child.
ANALYSIS: The Chief Administrator and Clinical Foster Care Supervisor
acknowledged that an assessment of progress was not
documented in the service plan/PATP. A review of the PATP
noted that progress was not documented.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that the agency did not provide the service plan in a timely manner
to the Court as required by policy.
INVESTIGATION:
During the August 27, 2020 interview with the Chief Administrator she reported that
Staff 1 had mistakenly sent to the Court a July 2019 Child Protective Services report
prior to the June 4, 2020 Court hearing. The February 21, 2020 to May 20, 2020,
USP was not sent to the Court prior to the June 4, 2020 Court hearing. She reported
that the USP should have been sent along with the agency Updated Court report
dated May 22, 2020.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-09 Foster Care – Updated Service Plan
A copy of the USP must be sent to the court prior to the
regularly scheduled review. Through the USP, the foster care
worker updates the court on progress and makes
recommendations regarding services and on-going planning
for the child and family. At the review the court may modify
the plan.
6

ANALYSIS: The Chief Administrator acknowledged that Staff 1 had not sent
the USP to the Court prior to the June 4, 2020 Court hearing.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that the agency did not provide reasonable efforts towards
reunification.
Document Review:
A review of a Court report addendum dated June 12, 2020, and the file, indicates
that various services for the bio-parents have been provided. They are Individual
counseling for each bio parent through a counselor at Alcona Behavioral Heath,
MSU Extension on-line parenting classes during the COVID restrictions, and a
referral for Supportive Visitation program at Catholic Human Services. There was
also a referral for the bio-father to Old Town Psychological, and psychological
evaluations for each bio-parent were conducted. Gas cards and other services were
provided.
A review of parenting time in the social work contacts indicates that parenting time,
in person and via video conferencing during COVID has been occurring 2-3 times
weekly. FTM’s have been held at the required junctures.
During the August 27, 2020, interview with the Chief Administrator she reported that
in person parenting time was suspended during COVD and the Court did not feel
that on-line parenting was sufficient. She also reported that the counselor for each
bio-parent would not return phone calls or provide the agency with counseling
attendance records for each bio-parent. The counselor was eventually subpoenaed
by the Court and at the Court hearing the agency received attendance reports. The
Chief Administrator reiterated services documented in the Court report and the file.
On August 31, 2020, Staff 2, a Foster Care Worker for the case, was interviewed.
She reported that she had made several attempts to obtain counseling reports for
the bio-parents from the counselor and only received them at a recent Court hearing.
She reported that the bio-parents are attending Supportive Visitation, a 12-14 week
program through Catholic Human Services. She stated that the Court has approved
of this program.
Document Review:
The foster care file was reviewed.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-08C Parent/Agency Treatment Plan
The treatment plan and services agreement should be specific
to the individual needs of the family and child(ren), express
their view-points and be written in a manner easily understood
by the family with expected outcomes clearly defined.
ANALYSIS: A review of documents, social work contacts, and the file
indicate that reasonable efforts have been provided to the bio-
parents to assist in reunification. Interviews with the Chief
Administrator and Staff 2 support that reasonable efforts are
being made.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan the recommendation is for
continuance of the regular license.
